newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS - PRESS DIGEST - Australian Business News - Sept 16.
newsitem.headline: RTRS - PRESS DIGEST - Australian Business News - Sept 16.

text.p: (Compiled for Reuters by Media Monitors)
THE AUSTRALIAN FINANCIAL REVIEW

A record-breaking surge on US stockmarkets should see Australian stock prices continue to rise today after the Australian market regained some momentum on Friday at the end of a bad week which saw resource stocks hit hard. Financial service sector stocks are likely to be boosted by the prospect of a fall in money market rates. Page 1.

According to the latest survey by a recruitment firm, EL Consulting, demand in the executive job market fell 2 per cent during August, but strong demand in infrastructure for engineering executives points to better times ahead - openings for engineers in New South Wales and Victoria rose by more than 20 per cent while demand for general-management executives rose by 28 per cent. Page 3.

Tax practitioners have started a push to have the capital gains tax rollover and retirement concessions announced in the Federal Budget changed so they are available to businesses owned through a company structure. Page 3.

According to Australian Bureau of Statistics figures, the manufacturing industry posted profits before tax of A$1.75 billion in the June quarter - a slide of 36 per cent. Declining demand and increasing import competition in some sectors have contributedto the dive in profits. Page 4.

Australia's three national pay TV operators lost almost A$600 million in the year to June in their battle to capture Australian subscribers. Australis Media Ltd and Foxtel announced last week that they had lost A$251.7 million and A$165 million respectivly, while Optus Vision earlier reported a A$159 million loss. Page 20.

Rural merchandising group IAMA Ltd has launched a A$43 million share takeover offer for Queensland pastoral house Primac Holdings Ltd , offering nine IAMA shares for every 10 Primac shares. The offer values Primac at A$2.52, well
below Primac's close on Fiday of A$3.10. Page 21.
THE AUSTRALIAN

In a speech to the Reserve Bank conference in July on the future of the financial system, Westpac Banking Corp Ltd managing director Bob Joss said banks would have to shut down entire divisions of business activity in order to survive. Joss said banks would have to depend more on the self-employed, farmers and small to medium enterprises as the rest of the lending industry became securitised. Page 17.

While the Colonial group sees the good response to National Mutual Holdings' share-versus-cash offer as a good omen for its planned float next year, it has urged shareholders and analysts to understand the differences between NatMut and Colonial. Colonial's chief financial officer Paul Batchelor said the group boasts a more diverse revenue stream, a stronger ability to pay ongoing franked dividends and less volatile earnings. Page 19.

The Australian Business Chamber and the State Bank of New South Wales yesterday criticised the Federal Government's economic policy settings and warned that new business investment and jobs growth were being held back because the Budget had failed to linka responsible fiscal outcome with appropriate industry policy setting. Page 19.

Huntley Investment Co Ltd director Ian Huntley has questioned the objectivity of a document prepared by Lonsdale Securities to evaluate First State Fund Managers' bid to take investment management control of Huntley, claiming the statement
of qualificatios and declarations in the report shows that Lonsdale and First State had an existing commercial relationship. Page 19.

AGL Ltd, Boral Energy, Wesfarmers Kleenheat and the Government-owned gas utility AlintaGas have been invited by the West Australian Government to submit proposals which could result in the first purely commercial gas reticulation operation in the State, in the inland City of Kalgoorlie-Boulder. Page 19.

In his book The Decline of the Age of Oil, former Perth engineer Brian Fleay says that the world's supply of cheap-to-produce crude oil will begin to run out some time during the next decade. Fleay's claims are backed up by London-based oil industry analsts Petroconsultants, who point out that all the world has now been explored for oil and there are no more big cheap-to-extract fields left undiscovered. Page 19.
THE SYDNEY MORNING HERALD

After announcing a A$133 million annual net loss last week, Pacific Dunlop has redefined itself as a manufacturer, with tyres, cables, batteries and the clothing and sporting goods manufacturing business Pacific Brands making up its core businesses. Despite the huge loss, PacDun shares rose five cents to A$2.70 on Friday. Page 35.

Owing mobile phone group Vodafone an estimated A$50 million, Martin Madden of Arthur Andersen was appointed as receiver and manager of Digicall last Friday. Vodafone spokesman Jim Macnamara said yesterday that Vodafone would continue to
support Digicall and would like to see it continue to operate. Page 35.

According to a Reserve Bank report to be released today, dramatic forces of change from new forms of saving, packaging or securitised lending and the undoing of traditional bank products by new low-cost entrants have endangered the future of banks. Page 5.

After announcing a A$251 million annual loss, the rally in the US bond market over the weekend will hearten pay TV group Australis Media Ltd, following comments by finance director Geoff Kleeman that the proposed US$150 million bond issue would be difficut to complete. Page 37.

According to a survey conducted by accountants Coopers and Lybrand, profit after tax for the insurance sector nearly doubled this year to A$428 million from A$239 million in 1994-95. The survey suggested an absence of major natural disasters, strong premum growth and acquisitions have boosted
the performance of Australia's listed insurers. Page 37.

The latest monthly survey of the executive recruitment market by EL Consulting reveals strong gains in some sectors in New South Wales and solid activity in Victoria, despite a two per cent national fall in executive demand. EL Australia managing director Grant Montgomery says the outlook is good, with signs that business and the larger State public sectors are giving way to more expansionary executive recruitment. Page 37. --
THE AGE

The Mobile phone group, Vodafone, has appointed a receiver and manager, Martin Madden of Arthur Anderson, to its largest reseller, Digicall, after the collapse of negotiations on Digicall's financial problems. Page C1.

A volume of papers released today from the Reserve Bank conference on The Future of the Financial System reveals widespread agreement that the financial system, in Australia and globally, is facing irreversible changes that will see bank profits shrink an financial institutions converge under the force of new competitors, including electronic bank providers.
Page C2.

The Australia Business Chamber and the State Bank of New South Wales have reported that manufacturing sales and profitability are still declining, and manufacturers expect to lay off another 15,000 employees in the next year. Page C3.

The Industry Commission will today recommend that tariffs on medical and scientific equipment be abolished, and that the industry's regulator, the Therapeutic and Goods Administration, should go as well to make way for the adoption of a flexible
system lie that of the European Commission. Page C3.

The Commonwealth Bank recently announced its A$2.5 billion Business Asset Finance program which will issue loans on the basis of cash-producing assets without the need for bricks-and-mortar security. This will mean small businesses with sound financial hstories will no longer have to use such assets as the family home for security when applying for business loans. Page C4.

Chairperson of the Industry Research and Development board's competitive grants committee, Leanna Read, said the availability of Government support and private investment was skewed to the early stages of R&D, with little or no equity support for companie at the crucial period between early product development and the development capital and commercialisation phases when the need for money escalated. Page C4.
-- Sydney Newsroom 61-2 373-1800
